questions.question: What is the mean of the dataset: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10?
What does a p-value represent?
options: Probability that null hypothesis is true
Probability of observing data if null hypothesis is true
questions.explanation: P-value is the probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as observed, assuming null hypothesis is true

questions.question: What is standard deviation?
options: Measure of spread around the mean
questions.explanation: Standard deviation measures how spread out data points are from the mean

questions.question: What does the correlation coefficient (r) indicate?
options: The slope of the regression line
Strength and direction of linear relationship
questions.explanation: Correlation coefficient indicates how strongly two variables are linearly related and in what direction

questions.question: If variance is 25, what is the standard deviation?
questions.explanation: Standard deviation = √variance = √25 = 5

questions.question: Which of the following is not a measure of central tendency?
questions.explanation: Variance measures spread, not central tendency

questions.question: What type of distribution has mean < median < mode?
questions.explanation: In a negatively skewed distribution, the mean is less than the median and mode

questions.question: In hypothesis testing, what is a Type I error?
options: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis
questions.explanation: Type I error occurs when we wrongly reject a true null hypothesis (false positive)

questions.question: What is the area under the entire normal distribution curve?
questions.explanation: The total probability under the normal distribution curve is always 1

questions.question: Which measure is most affected by extreme values?
questions.explanation: The mean is sensitive to outliers since it uses all data points in calculation

questions.question: What does an R² value of 0.9 indicate in regression?
options: 90% of variation is explained by the model
Regression line passes through all points
questions.explanation: R² of 0.9 means 90% of the variability in dependent variable is explained by the independent variable(s)

questions.question: In a normal distribution, approximately what percentage of data lies within 1 standard deviation of the mean?
questions.explanation: According to the empirical rule, about 68% of data falls within ±1 SD of the mean

questions.question: What is the z-score formula?
questions.explanation: Z = (x - μ) / σ measures how many standard deviations a value is from the mean

questions.question: Which test is used to compare means of two independent groups?
questions.explanation: Independent t-test compares means between two separate groups

questions.question: What does the central limit theorem state?
options: Sample mean distribution tends to normal as sample size increases
Sample variance always decreases with size
questions.explanation: Central Limit Theorem states that, regardless of population distribution, the sampling distribution of the mean approaches normality as sample size increases

questions.question: What is the median of the dataset: 3, 7, 9, 15, 21?
questions.explanation: The median is the middle value when data is ordered. In this dataset, 9 is the middle (3rd) value.

questions.question: What is the mode of the dataset: 2, 4, 4, 6, 8, 4, 10?
questions.explanation: The mode is the most frequently occurring value. 4 appears three times, more than any other value.

questions.question: What is a Type II error in hypothesis testing?
options: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis
questions.explanation: Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative).

questions.question: What does a confidence interval represent?
options: The exact value of a population parameter
A range likely to contain the population parameter
The probability that data is correct
questions.explanation: A confidence interval provides a range of values within which we expect the true population parameter to fall with a certain level of confidence.

questions.question: In a normal distribution, approximately what percentage of data lies within 2 standard deviations of the mean?
questions.explanation: According to the empirical rule (68-95-99.7), about 95% of data falls within ±2 SD of the mean.

questions.question: What is the interquartile range (IQR)?
options: The difference between maximum and minimum values
The difference between Q3 and Q1
questions.explanation: IQR = Q3 - Q1, representing the range of the middle 50% of the data and is resistant to outliers.

questions.question: Which statistical test is used to determine if there's a relationship between two categorical variables?
questions.explanation: Chi-square test assesses whether there is a significant association between two categorical variables.

questions.question: What does ANOVA stand for?
questions.explanation: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used to compare means across three or more groups.

questions.question: What is the difference between population and sample?
options: Population is entire group, sample is subset
Population is always known, sample is estimated
questions.explanation: Population includes all members of a defined group, while a sample is a subset selected from the population for analysis.

questions.question: What does a correlation coefficient of -0.85 indicate?
questions.explanation: A correlation of -0.85 indicates a strong negative (inverse) linear relationship between two variables.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the null hypothesis?
options: To state there is no effect or difference
questions.explanation: The null hypothesis (H₀) assumes no effect, no difference, or no relationship. We test whether data provides enough evidence to reject it.

questions.question: What is sampling error?
options: The difference between sample statistic and population parameter
questions.explanation: Sampling error is the natural variation between a sample statistic and the true population parameter due to random chance.

questions.question: Which measure of variability is calculated by taking the square root of variance?
questions.explanation: Standard deviation (σ or s) is the square root of variance and is in the same units as the original data.

questions.question: What is the significance level (alpha) typically set at in hypothesis testing?
questions.explanation: Common significance levels are 0.05 (most common), 0.01 (more stringent), and 0.10 (less stringent). Choice depends on the context.

questions.question: What does a positive skew in a distribution indicate?
options: Tail extends to the right (mean > median)
questions.explanation: Positive (right) skew means the tail extends toward higher values, and typically mean > median > mode.

questions.question: What is the coefficient of variation (CV)?
options: The ratio of standard deviation to mean, expressed as a percentage
The difference between maximum and minimum values
The slope of the regression line
questions.explanation: CV is calculated as (standard deviation / mean) * 100 and measures relative variability.

questions.question: What is the mode in a dataset?
options: The most frequent value in the dataset
The middle value when data is ordered
questions.explanation: Mode is the value that appears most frequently in the dataset.

questions.question: Which statistical measure is least sensitive to outliers?
questions.explanation: Median is a robust measure of central tendency and is less affected by extreme values.

questions.question: What is sampling bias?
options: Systematic error from non-random sample selection
questions.explanation: Sampling bias occurs when the selected sample is not representative of the population causing systematic errors.

questions.question: Which test is used to check if the means of three or more groups are significantly different?
questions.explanation: ANOVA tests hypotheses on whether the means of three or more independent groups differ significantly.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a histogram?
options: To show frequency distribution of continuous data
To show relationships between two variables
questions.explanation: Histograms visualize the distribution of numerical data grouped into bins (intervals).

questions.question: Which of the following is true about a box plot?
options: Shows data distribution with median, quartiles, and outliers
Shows frequency counts of categorical variables
questions.explanation: Box plots summarize data with median, quartiles, and identify outliers.

questions.question: What is a Type II error in hypothesis testing?
options: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis
questions.explanation: Type II error occurs when we do not reject the null hypothesis even though it is false (false negative).

questions.question: Which distribution is described as symmetric and bell-shaped?
questions.explanation: Normal distribution has a characteristic bell shape and is symmetric about the mean.

questions.question: What does the term 'p-value < 0.05' typically indicate?
options: Strong evidence against the null hypothesis
No evidence against the alternative hypothesis
questions.explanation: A p-value less than 0.05 generally suggests evidence to reject the null hypothesis at 5% significance level.
